abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, but only modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight
            primarily, the need for greater discretionary authority,
            regarding availability of funds, and decisions on costs, and
            expenses, as it relates to the timing for an effective
            plantation management, and optimal forest product yields,
            particularly, in a country such as Bangladesh, whose current
            system of budgetary allocation, and control precludes a
            timely funding. It is thus strongly suggested, that future
            projects involving industrial plantation development, and
            management, include definitive measures, in addition to the
            necessary legal covenants, to ensure these shortcomings are
            overcome: the establishment of a financially autonomous
            entity, having a commercial management approach with the
            Government, local communities, and possibly in partnership
            with the private sector, is an avenue worth exploring. While
            the project demonstrated that mangrove establishment on
            accreted silt beds, can stabilize these beds, and lead to
            the formation of new land masses, suitable for agriculture,
            the sustainable management of mangrove plantations however,
            will depend on such practice being a sound legal basis for
            tenure, with agreed policies for mangrove disposition. But,
            the effective development of forests, and protection of
            wildlife will not be possible, without appropriate
            consideration of the needs, and the involvement of marginal
            populations adjacent to the forests.
